params.text:
Weeds compete with the crop in its requirement. For weed management, the following is recommended:

 

  1. Weed by hand pulling, hoeing or by shallow cultivation.

  2. Apply herbicide following the manufacturer’s recommendation. 

  3. Cultivate properly the soil around the plants, avoiding root injury because papaya is shallow rooted.

  4. Practice mulching during the dry season to control growth of weeds and to conserve moisture.

items.description:
1. Mites.  The red spider mites (Tetranychus kanzawai Kishida) is the most common insect attacking and severely damaging the older leaves of papaya and its seedlings. It causes the leaves to dry up, thus, reducing the photosynthetic activity of the plant.

 

Control measures: 

 

  • To prevent the sources and build-up of mite population, leaf pruning and burning of damaged and attacked leaves are done weekly and; 

  • For chemical control, use selective miticides sprayed at 7 to 10 days interval.

1. Scale insects.  The most common scale insect species colonizing and feeding on papaya fruit is the Aspidiotus destructor Sig. Their feeding caused the fruit to ripen prematurely and destroy the external appearance of the fruits.

 

Control measures: 

 

  • Spray recommended insecticide directly to the fruits 15 days before harvest to control incidence of scale insects in the fruits.

  • Adjust spray nozzle so as not to hit harvestable fruit in case there are available harvestable fruits. 

  • Re-spray seven days after if presence of pest is still observed.

1. Fruit Fly.  Dacus dorsalis and Dacus cucurbitae Coq. are species of fruit fly attacking papaya. When an outbreak in population occurs, the eggs are deposited in the ripening fruits while they are still attached to the tree. Harvested fruits eventually rot as the newly hatched larvae start to feed inside the fruit.

 

Control measures: 

  • Practice sanitation inside the population by gathering all ripened, damaged and fallen fruits. 

  • Gathered fruits should be dumped in pit and burned.

  • Use Methyl Eugenol to attract male files and kill them.

  • Do not allow ripe fruits to remain in the tree for some time.
